para.paratext: Under Fed. R. Evid. 407, evidence of any subsequent remedial measures is not admissible on the issue of negligence in a product liability case to prove “a defect in a product, a defect in a product's design, or a need for a warning or instruction.”

Unlike the federal courts, Georgia courts have held evidence of subsequent remedial measures to be admissible in the product liability context to prove issues other than negligence.[1] In adopting O.C.G.A. § 24-4-407, Georgia retained its prior policy. “Georgia's version of Federal Rule 407 also clarifies that the rule excludes remedial measures that follow an injury or harm but without the apparent limitation in the Federal Rule that the remedial measure must have followed the injury or harm to the plaintiff in the subject lawsuit.”[2]

In civil proceedings, when, after an injury or harm, remedial measures are taken to make such injury or harm less likely to recur, evidence of the remedial measures shall not be admissible to prove negligence or culpable conduct but may be admissible to prove product liability under subsection (b) or (c) of Code Section 51-1-11. The provisions of this Code section shall not require the exclusion of evidence of remedial measures when offered for impeachment or for another purpose, including, but not limited to, proving ownership, control, or feasibility of precautionary measures, if controverted.

Evidence of remedial measures is admissible if the defendant opens the door for such evidence. In Brooks v. Cellin Mfg. Co., Inc.,[3] the defendant installed insulation on top of recessed ceiling lights in a building's attic, causing sufficient heat to build up and ignite the insulation. After the fire, the defendant removed insulation that it had installed on top of ceiling lights in other buildings. The defendant testified at trial that the other buildings had not caught fire even though the defendant had installed the same type of insulation. The plaintiff was prevented from introducing evidence showing that the defendant had removed the insulation in the other buildings. The Georgia Supreme Court reversed and held that defendant had opened the door regarding its remedial measures because the jury was left with the misleading impression that there had been no fires in the other buildings even though the insulation was left on top of the lights. The plaintiff should have been afforded the opportunity to demonstrate what changes had been made by the defendant.

Likewise, evidence that a surgeon had changed his practice of installing a medical device following a suit for malpractice was inadmissible where the doctor wanted to introduce evidence that the device could be installed in two different ways. The doctor's proposed evidence was not contradictory to his practice and therefore did not open the door for the change in practices to come in for impeachment purposes.[4]

The case of Stuckey's Carriage Inn v. Phillips[5] restated the rule that evidence of remedial measures after an injury is not admissible to prove negligence. Here the plaintiff contended that the defendant had not provided an adequate pest-control program. Evidence that the existing pest-control contract was cancelled because of dissatisfaction with the service and a new contract was awarded to another company after the plaintiff was injured was improperly admitted.

Suggestions for improving safety included in an accident investigation report completed by a defendant's employee are inadmissible as remedial measures unless defendant opens the door to such evidence by eliciting testimony regarding the suggestions.[6]

In a case of first impression, Moody v. Southland Investment Corp.,[7] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the cost of providing safeguards was admissible on the issue of their feasibility for minimizing danger where plaintiff walked through a sheet glass door and sought to introduce evidence relating to the cost difference between installing sheet glass and tempered glass.

Later, the court adopted guidelines regarding the admissibility of remedial measures in product liability cases in General Motors Corp. v. Moseley.[8] Remedial measures are admissible (1) to prove some fact of the case on trial other than a belated awareness of negligence, (2) to show notice/knowledge of the defect, (3) to show causation, (4) to rebut a contention that it was impossible for the accident to have happened in the manner claimed, and (5) to show the feasibility of repair or modification when this is in issue.

See General Motors Corp. v. Moseley, 213 Ga. App. 875, 882, 447 S.E.2d 302 (1994) (abrogated on other grounds by, Webster v. Boyett, 269 Ga. 191, 496 S.E.2d 459 (1998)); Savannah F. & W. Ry. Co. v. Flanagan, 82 Ga. 579, 9 S.E. 471 (1889); Georgia Southern & F. Ry. Co. v. Cartledge, 116 Ga. 164, 42 S.E. 405 (1902); Brooks v. Cellin Mfg. Co., Inc., 251 Ga. 395, 306 S.E.2d 657 (1983); Flint River Cotton Mills v. Colley, 71 Ga. App. 288, 30 S.E.2d 426 (1944); Lacy v. City of Atlanta, 110 Ga. App. 814, 140 S.E.2d 144 (1964).

“Evidence of subsequent remedial measures generally is inadmissible in negligence actions, because the admission of such evidence basically conflicts with the public policy of encouraging safety through remedial action, for the instituting of remedial safety measures might be discouraged if such conduct is admissible as evidence of negligence.” Wynn v. City of Warner Robins, 279 Ga. App. 42, 49, 630 S.E.2d 574 (2006); Henson v. Georgia-Pacific Corp., 289 Ga. App. 777, 658 S.E.2d 391 (2008).
